Award.AwardTitle: A novel technique using pairs of small telescopes to measure the sizes of nearby stars
Award.AbstractNarration:
Astronomers at Arizona State University (ASU) have developed a novel new instrument that can be used to measure the size of bright stars and to separate stars that exist as a close pair and orbit each other. Known as an "interferometer", the instrument comprises two small telescopes which, when used together, act like a much larger telescope. Each telescope is only 50 centimeters in diameter. The telescopes are mounted on the roof of the School of Earth and Space Exploration at ASU. New cameras, developed by the project's principal investigator (PI) and his students, are being used on the two telescopes to take many thousands of images very quickly. By studying these sequences of images carefully the team can check for the dimming of the star as a planet passes in front of it. The equipment can also be used to study the "blinking" of very rapidly rotating stars known as "pulsars". Engagement with amateur astronomy communities is planned through monthly public demonstrations of the rooftop interferometer. The equipment will also be used to teach graduate and undergraduate students about the technique and the specialized cameras being used. The PI also hopes to eventually take the equipment to the Kitt Peak Observatory so that it can be tested on larger telescopes.

The PI, along with a graduate student, aims to obtain high angular resolution observations of nearby bright stars using intensity interferometry with two or possibly more 8 to 18 inch telescopes. The telescopes will be coupled to single-photon detectors, which the PI and his students have been characterizing in their lab. The main science goal is to measure the angular size of each star by observing single photons from the same star with multiple telescopes and time-tagging them. In this way angular resolutions corresponding to the size of the telescope separations can be achieved. The measured stellar radii will be compared to other stellar properties, such as temperature, to improve our understanding of convection in main sequence stars and ultimately the equation of state. Secondary science goals include resolving close binaries, high-speed photometry of known exoplanet transits, and long-term high-speed monitoring of pulsars. The detectors that comprise the interferometer each fit within a module that can be moved to other telescopes; stage 2 of the project involves coupling these single photon counting detector modules to larger (1 and 4 meter) telescopes at Kitt Peak via fiber-optic cable. Stage 1 - commissioning of the interferometer using the smaller telescopes at Arizona State University - has already begun.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Light is detected in quantized units called photons. In the last 10 years or so, detectors capable of detecting individual photons have become commercially available. These single photon detectors use either silicon or superconductors and generate a fast electrical pulse whenever an individual photon is detected.

This project aimed to develop a low cost system to measure the arrival times of single photons at multiple detectors and demonstrate this system by measuring the correlation between photons from a single unresolved source detected with two separate detectors. Finding this correlated signal is like searching for a needle in a haystack. Photons are a type of particle called a boson which likes to pair up whenever possible. This property of photons is sometimes called 'bunching' - photons from very hot thermal sources tend to arrive in 'bunches'.

Other particles, like electrons are Fermions and they are not able to be in the same state as each other so they tend to 'antibunch'. The bunching or antibunch effect is only observable when there are a very large number of particles. For light from a star or lamp in the laboratory, only about one out of every 10,000 or 100,000 photons that arrives at a detector is paired with another photon. Also, the bunching effect occurs over a very small time interval called the coherence time of the light. This means that in order to observe this signal, we need a system of two detectors that can:

1. Detect individual photons with high efficiency

2. Detect large numbers of photons in a short amount of time (i.e. millions of photons per second) to build up statitstics and

3. Measure the arrival times of the photons as accurately as possible to distinguish real 'bunching' events from random arrival of 'unbunched' photons.

Single photon detectors that can produce pulses for a million photons per second with a timing resolution of about 250 picoseconds each are available commercially so we bought two of these detectors. However, electronics that can take the output of these detectors in the form of electrical pulses and convert this into a set of time stamps and then store all of these times in a computer file are not commercially available and/or cost a lot of money - more than the budget for this entire project.

So, we decided to build our own time-tagging electronics using a low cost open source electronics board developed by a group at Berkeley to help with the search for extraterrestrial intelligence. The group is called The Collaboration for Astronomy Signal Processing and Electronics Research (CASPER - casper.berkeley.edu) and they designed a fast electronics board called the Roconfigurable Open Architecture Computing Hardware (ROACH) board that has really fast digital electronics on it - it could be run with steps as fast as 4 nanoseconds.

However, this was still not fast enough. We needed to go faster than the detector speed of 250 picoseconds (or 16 times faster than the ROACH board). So, we cheated. We used some tricks to run the electronics such that we were able to time stamp the pulses from the detectors with a precision of better than 100 picoseconds. We effectively ran the board 40 times faster than it was supposed to be able to run. The details of how we did it are in the PhD thesis that came out of this project (Pilyavsky, PhD thesis, 2018).

We also designed an interface board to allow us to read in pulses from up to 10 detectors and time stamp them all at a rate of over 1 million pulses per second. We created a system that could be expanded to hundreds of detectors and has a manufacturing cost of less than $10k. This is useful not only for measuring correlated photons from stars which is our main goal but also for receiving signals from optical communications and for optical quantum computing.

Finally, we tested the system in the lab. The schematic for the setup is shown in the first attached image. The results of measuring the correlated photon signal is shown in the second attached image. The small peaks visible in the blue trace are from correlated signals while the orange trace is the same setup run in a configuration where no correlations are expected. This system is now being used to measure correlated light from stars and determine their diameters with low cost telescopes that belong to local amateur astronomers.
